Lab sewage to be re-directed
By CAROL TRZCINSKI
Plans are presently being made
by the Office of Physical Plant
and Planning to divert the flow
of chemical refuse coming from
on-campus laboratory drains to
the city's sewage system. in order
to eliminate the chemical
discharge presently being
directed into one of the city's
public waterways.
The drainage systems from
Hopkins' chemistry and biology
laboratories have, for the past
twenty years, been emptying
their refuse into a storm drainage
stream located in back of the
Hopkins Club. This stream
eventually runs into Stoney Run,
and is accessible to the
communities bordering it.
Bill Campbell, Director of the
office now working on the new
drainage system, stated that this
practice had always
been
conducted with sanction from
Baltimore city. Now, because of
pressure from ecological groups,
action is being taken to modify
the method of disposal.
The new plan would call for
the installation of an
underground pumping station
which would enter the refuse
into Baltimore City's sewage
system during normal weather

conditions.
In the case •of storm
conditions, the discharge would
once again be thwarted into its
present disposal site, to be
diluted and washed away by the
rain waters.
"During storm conditions, the
sewage system Would not be able
to handle the run-off from the
storm in addition to the flow
which has, up till now, been
diverted into the storm drainage
system," Campbell explained
about the alternating system.

Bill Campbell

Campbell gave assurances that
the chemical content of the fluid
presently being discharged into
the storm drain was not of a
detrimental nature should it
come in contact with the skin.
"The chemicals are not of a
concentration that would cause
skin irritation upon contact," he
stated.
"The material becomes so
diluted by the time it hits Stoney
Run, that it is relatively
harmless."
Campbell stated that none of
the discharge running out was
radioactive.
Cambell cited the cost of
dividing the laboratory draining
system as the main reason for not
having previously taken steps to
alternatively deal with the
problem.
"We're requesting $200,000
dollars from the University's
Capital Fund Budget for the
division of the drains," Campbell
said.
The Plant Planning Director
stated that, provided funding was
arranged by July 1, when the
University's new fiscal year
begins, the redirectioning process
could be finished by September
1, in time for next year's use by
undergraduates.

Zhores A. Medvedev to speak tomorrow
By LOUISA DAVIS
Zhores A. Medvedev, a Russian
biologist who has earned
world-wide recognition for both
his criticism of Russia's
treatment of her scientists and
for his work on genetic and
molecular problems in
gerontology, will speak at
Hopkins tomorrow at 4 p.m. in
Shaffer three.
He will address the topic
"Science and Scientists in the
Soviet Union."
Medvedev once worked on
gerontological studies, dealing
with the decline of life in old age,
at several Russian research
centers but was removed from his
professional posts after he had
publicly criticized his country's
policies towards scientists. While
lecturing in England last year, his
passport and Russian citizenship
were revoked.
Medvedev will speak at the
invitation of Dr. Harry Woolf,
University Provost.
"Dr. Woolf had learned that he
(Medvedev) was in the country
and phoned him last week to
invite him to speak here. We're
fortunate to have him here on
such short notice and I'd like to
see people there," commented
Christopher Shinkman, Assistant
to the P-ovost who is in charge of
organizing the event.
According to a news release.
Dr. Medvedev "has known
Personally the Soviet techniques
of punishing dissidents by placing
them in mental institutions."

"Medvedev was accused of
being insane since he was doing
things not expected of a biologist
— he was too politically active,"
explained Jerome Gilison,
Russian specialist in the Hopkins
Political Science Department.
"His most recent book, The
Question ofMadness, is a memoir
of his experiences at an asylum
for six months. It was written
with his brother, a historian of
the Stalin era," continued
Gilison.
"He has apparently done some
work in science, of international

acclaim. He was well-known
enough so that when he got into
trouble, he was supported by
scientists around the world," said
Gilison.
Gilison also added, "I would
assume that as a scientist and as a
spokesman for the scientific
community who has been
advocating changes in the system
to allow less governmental
interference, Medvedev was a
problem."
Medvedev has two other books
translated in English. The
Medvedev Papers, according to

the news release, "criticized the
restrictions, censorship and
surveillance that oppress many
Russian intellectuals." His book
The Rise and Fall of T.D.
Lysenko is a career biography of
a Russian geneticist under Stalin
whose work has since been
discredited.
Medvedev grew up in
Leningrad and served in the
Russian Army during WW II. He
studied after the war at
Timiryazev Agricultural
Academy in Moscow where he
graduated in 1950.

Bentsen speaks on Presidency: the way it should be
By STEVE DUBNER
U.S. Senator Lloyd M.
Bentsen, Jr. addressed a group
yesterday in the Garrett Room of
the Eisenhower Library on "The
Presidency: Its Nature and
Scope."
University President Muller
introduced Bentsen to the
approximately fifty people
assembled. Bentsen, a Democrat
from Texas dealt with a variety
of topics concerning the office of
the President in his half hour
talk. Included were the
President's role as a politician,
party head, Commander in Chief,
and Chief Executive. Bentsen
also touched upon such issues as

the decline of Congressional
power, the right of the public to
register its opinion, and
impeachment.
"A President is required to be
many things to millions of
people. Above all, I think he
should be a politician...able to
translate public opinion into
action," stated Bentsen.
He also noted that since "a
President can't conduct his
business within a vacuum," the
ability to work with both
political parties is essential.
Among his other observations,
Bentsen asserted that "I see the
President as an analyst of
legislation. He should execute.

laws, not kill them." He stressed
the point that while the President
is free to offer legislation of his
own, he should not contradict
Congress. •
He also emphasized that a
good President can delegate his
authority to responsible
subordinates. Bentsen stated that
"the Chief Executive is not the
sole executive" and urged that a
strong Cabinet be placed above
any "small White House clique."
Furthermore, he noted that "it's
an unwise President who
bypasses his Cabinet" and that a
President can be judged by the
type of people he delegates
authority to.

Verdict pending on coed dorms
By SUE EYRICH
In approximately ten days, the
University will decide whether or
not to expand coeducational
Housing on campus for next
year.
The principal factors involved
in the decision will be the
number of female applicants that
accept their admission offers, and
the number of next year's
Freshman who indicate a desire
for coed housing, Peter Heist,
University Housing Director,
revealed yesterday.
"The University is committed
to coed dorms and hopes to
expand the existing facilities,"
said Heist.
Two of the suggested houses
for conversion are Jennings
House in the new dorm complex
and the joint Vincent-Willard

House in the old dorm complex.
Heist pointed out that he
thought the complaint of many
old dorm residents that they
deserved coeducational housing
as much as new dorm residents
was "a valid one."
Jennings was suggested for
conversion because of its
proximity to Lazear, presently
Hopkins' only coed dormitory. If
Jennings is selected a new
housemaster plan would
probably be implemented,
according to Heist, whereby the
housemasters of both Jennings
and Lazear would share the
responsibility for the dorms.
Last year when an
unprecedented number of girls
opted for dormitory housing, the
Housing Office found itself in a
difficult satiation, Heist stated.

Bentsen spent much of his talk
discussing the decline of
Congressional power. Fixing as
much blame on Congress as on
the executive branch, he said that
there is "too much spotlight on
the White House." Even though
he feels that most people favor a
strong President, he expressed a
desire for greater Congressional
authority in the future.
President and Public
Another topic Bentsen
considered was the President's
relation with the public. Urging a
more candid attitude on the part
of the President, he deplored the
inacessibilify of the Chief
Executive.
He proposed more frequent
press conferences in order to
increase the President's
accountability to the public.

A crowd estimated by a
District of Columbia police
official to have reached ten

favor of Congressional action to
impeach the President.
The rally was the culmination
of weeks of lobbying, protest
marches and demonstrations
organized by the National
Committee to Impeach the
President. Simultaneous
demonstrations were held in Los
Angeles and Chicago.
The crowd was orderly, and
cooperative with the D.C. police
as few incidents occurred during
the day. The march began at the
reflecting pool in front of the
Lincoln Memorial and followed
Constitution Ave., to 15th St.
and then onto Pennsylvania
Avenue, stopping traffic all the
way to the Capitol for almost an
hour. A large stage was set up on
the mall in front of the Capitol
and a rock and roll band started
playing as the first of the
marchers arrived.

Chants of "Throw the Bum
Out," "Impeachment Now," and
"Jail to the Chief" were typical
of the chants the protestors
shouted during the
demonstration.
The demonstration's speakers
included Maryland
Representative Parren J. Mitchell,
Chicago 7 defendant David
Dellinger, Attica Defendant
Herbert Blydon and rock singer
Phil Ochs, among others.
Mitchell, speaking to a
cheering crowd said, "The danger
to America is that a dangerous,
duplicitous, deceitful man is in
the White House. He went on to
say "We must get rid of him.
before he destroys this country."
All the demonstration speakers
warned that the rally "was
effortless when compared with
the burden which ensuing
political oppression would
present."
It appeared that the majority
of the protestors were young,
however, a considerable number
of middle-aged people did attend.
Small protest groups and
organizations comprised a large

part of the crowd. The
demonstrations were organized
by the National Committee to
Impeach Nixon (NCIN).
Among groups participating in
the march were; The Youth
International Party (YIP), The
Indochina Peace Campaign (IPC),
The United Farm Workers Union,
The Vietnam War Veterans, and
The Attica Brigade.
The day was one of orderly
protest, excepting a late
afternoon incident on the steps
of the Justice Dept. Several
hundred youths (mostly YIPs)
stoned the building, breaking
windows with bottles. Two men
were arrested in this, the only
violent incident of the
Demonstration.
The demonstration appeared
to be an extremely
well-organized one in which the
violence and chos of the 60's had
apparently been transcended.
Protestors of various crossections
of society massed to express
discontent with the President.

Rally to impeach the President draws ten thousand

By PETER ROWLAND and
P. OLIN ALBA
A crowd estimated by a
District of Columbia police
official to have reached ten
thousand marched on the
Nation's Capitol Saturday in
favor of Congressional action to
impeach the President.
The rally was the culmination
of weeks of lobbying, protest
marches and demonstrations
organized by the National
Committee to Impeach the
President. Simultaneous
demonstrations were held in Los
Angeles and Chicago.
The crowd was orderly, and
cooperative with the D.C. police
as few incidents occurred during
the day. The march began at the
reflecting pool in front of the
Lincoln Memorial and followed
Constitution Ave., to 15th St.
and then onto Pennsylvania
Avenue, stopping traffic all the
way to the Capitol for almost an
hour. A large stage was set up on
the mall in front of the Capitol
and a rock and roll band started
playing as the first of the
marchers arrived.

Chants of "Throw the Bum
Out," "Impeachment Now," and
"Jail to the Chief" were typical
of the chants the protestors
shouted during the
demonstration.
The demonstration's speakers
included Maryland
Representative Parren J. Mitchell,
Chicago 7 defendant David
Dellinger, Attica Defendant
Herbert Blydon and rock singer
Phil Ochs, among others.
Mitchell, speaking to a
cheering crowd said, "The danger
to America is that a dangerous,
duplicitous, deceitful man is in
the White House. He went on to
say "We must get rid of him.
before he destroys this country."
All the demonstration speakers
warned that the rally "was
effortless when compared with
the burden which ensuing
political oppression would
present."
It appeared that the majority
of the protestors were young,
however, a considerable number
of middle-aged people did attend.
Small protest groups and
organizations comprised a large

part of the crowd. The
demonstrations were organized
by the National Committee to
Impeach Nixon (NCIN).
Among groups participating in
the march were; The Youth
International Party (YIP), The
Indochina Peace Campaign (IPC),
The United Farm Workers Union,
The Vietnam War Veterans, and
The Attica Brigade.
The day was one of orderly
protest, excepting a late
afternoon incident on the steps
of the Justice Dept. Several
hundred youths (mostly YIPs)
stoned the building, breaking
windows with bottles. Two men
were arrested in this, the only
violent incident of the
Demonstration.
The demonstration appeared
to be an extremely
well-organized one in which the
violence and chos of the 60's had
apparently been transcended.
Protestors of various crossections
of society massed to express
discontent with the President.

Homewood nine beat Washington College 9-4
By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The Blue Jay diamondmen
helped make 3400 weekend a
delight for Hopkins sports
enthusiasts by turning back
visiting Washington College 9-4.
This conference victory lifted
their overall record to 7-9.
Starting for the Jays, Bill
Evans pitched the first six innings
before Coach Dennis Cox lifted
him for a fresh man in the
seventh. Ron Brown came on in
relief and hurled for one and
two-thirds before Ed Chory was
called on to get the final two
men out to preserve the victory
for Bill Evans and the Blue Jays.
Evans gave up all of Washington
College's four runs on seven hits,
walking two and striking out
four.
Washington College opened
quickly in the first inning scoring
a run on three looping singles.
They added another in the third
on a two base error by Jack
Bukowski and a double by
Washington's clean up man Paul
Brown.
Score Tied
Hopkins retaliated in their half
of the third. Lour Podrazik
singled and stole second. Jack
Bukowski got on base on an error
by the center fielder Glen St.
George. Both runners advanced
on a pass ball by pitcher Dave
Novak. Mike Bogdan grounded
out, bringing home a run, and
Billy Jones singled to tie the
score at 2-2.
In the fifth, Hopkins took the
lead when they rallied with two
outs. Bob Babb, Tony Pucillo
and Tom Pedroni all drew bases
on balls with two down, before
Lou Podrazik ripped a single
driving home Babb and Pucillo.
Hopkins was never behind again.
Washington College tied it up

in the top of the sixth but the
Blue Jays came right back in the
bottom of the sixth scoring four
runs to put the game out of reach
for the visitors.
Leading off the sixth, Tony
Pucillo smashed a triple to
left-center. Pedroni then drove a
ball to center scoring Pucillo.
Podrazik, Bukowski and Bogdan
hit consecutive singles to drive
home two more tallies. Jim
Duffy connected on a Novak
pitch for a two base hit scoring
the fourth run of the inning.
Coming in for Evans in the top

of the seventh, Ron Brown was
wild walking three batters in
both the seventh and eighth
frames before buckling down to
get the final out. Brown struck
out Kerry Crocken on a 3-2 pitch
ending the seventh and stopping
that rally. Brown also picked off
Phil Repucci with the bases
loaded in the eighth with two
down to stifle another
Washington College rally.
Star of the Day
Hopkins added a final run in
the eighth after two men were
out. Batting star of the day, Jim

Duffy, who hit four for four,
singled. Dave Travis followed
with a single. Catcher Phil
Repucci of Washington College
attempted to pick off Travis who
was leading off first base but
threw the ball away for a two
base error allowing Duffy to
score. This made the final score
9-4.
Blown continued to have
control problems in the ninth
and Cox replaced him with Ed
Chory who put the clamps on the
visitors, picking up the final two
outs. Chory picked up a save.

Hopkins' Linksters lose 5 of 6
By JOHN M. ALLAN, Jr.
The Hopkir golf team's
winning season took a drastic
nosedive with the Blue Jays
losing five out of six matches.
With a 5-7 record though the golf
team is still guaranteed an
improved record over last
season's record of 3-9 and is still
undefeated at home.
Friday, April 19, the Blue Jays
travelled to Carlisle, Pennsylvania
to face the golf team's rivals
Dickinson College, Muhlenberg
College and Delaware Valley in a
rare quadrangular match. The
total team scores were
Muhlenberg— 393 ,
Dickinson -397, Delaware
Valley-407 and Hopkins with a
411. The Blue Jay scorers were
led by match medalist Frank
Healey with a 74. He was
followed by Bob Ivanhoe with an
81, Steve Erdman with an 83,
Bob Schiemel with an 86 and
Skip Miller with an 87. The three
MAC losses dropped the Blue
Jay's conference record to 3-4
for the season.

Last Monday, the Homewood
linksters faced the Towson State
College golfers at the Mount
Pleasant Golf Course. The team
scored its only victory of the
week with a team total of 428 to.
Towson State's 439. The scorers
for Hopkins were match medalist
Steve Erdman -81, Bob
Ivanhoe-84, John Susko-86,
anf Frank Healey-87. Bob
Schiemel and Skip Miller tied for
the fifth spot with 90's.
Coach Win Smith's charges
travelled to Newark, Delaware on
Thursday, to face the University
Division golf teams of the
University of Delaware and
Villanova University. The total
team scores were Delaware-389,
Villanova-409 and the Blue Jays
436. Hopkins scorers were
Healey-81, Erdman-86, Bill
Blubaugh-87, Miller-90 and
Hynan with a 92.
This week concludes the
season for the Homewood
golfers. Final matches include the
MAC championships at Horshma,
Pennsylvania, a triangular match

against Gettysburg and Juniata
Colleges on Wednesday, and the
season closes on Friday with a
home match against Franklin and
Marshall College.
